On Aug. 29, China's ambassador to the Philippines, Zhao Jinhua, announced that Beijing was willing to hold bilateral talks with Manila and would "look into the possibility" of allowing Filipino fishermen to fish in the disputed waters, particularly around the Scarborough Shoal. So far China has responded well to his outreach, particularly as it struggles to manage the fallout of the ruling elsewhere and rising tension with Japan in the East China Sea. Of course, this by no means indicates that detente will come at the expense of the Philippines' maritime sovereignty. Duterte has proved himself to be a savvy politician, and he is undoubtedly trying to use the upper hand Manila has gained to pursue better economic deals with China while continuing to cooperate with other powers, such as Japan and the United States. One of the key concessions the Philippines has discussed with China is a proposal for joint fishing around the Scarborough Shoal. Since China seized it in 2012, the shoal has lain at the center of the maritime dispute between Manila and Beijing, both because of its proximity to the Philippine mainland (about 120 nautical miles) and because of the repeated clashes between Chinese and Philippine fishermen in the waters around it. (China has attempted to block foreign fishermen from tapping into the shoal's waters, which are rich with fish.) When the international court ruled against Beijing's claim to the shoal, fears arose that China would retaliate somehow, prompting the United States to warn against further "provocative action" on Beijing's part.  Since China hopes to avoid inciting a U.S. military response, its strategy around the Scarborough Shoal has effectively run its course. For now, at least, this has created room for cooperation with the Philippines, as has Manila's own efforts to regulate the activities of its fishermen in the area. Of course, any deal between the two countries would depend on their continuing political will to abide by it and on how broader disputes over China's claims in the South China Sea play out. Though a deal on joint fishing may not necessarily lead to broader cooperation in the South China Sea, it would prevent one of the most heated aspects of the dispute from escalating. China should avoid unilaterally declaring an air defense identification zone (ADIZ) over the South China Sea in order to help reduce tensions in the area, a leading Chinese scholar said Tuesday.

Regardless of prior precedent, China may propose to amend customary international law in relation to ADIZ by creating a new “Mandate of Heaven” in the SCS. The declaration of an ADIZ could lead to the material enforcement of China’s assertion of “undisputed sovereignty” and “related rights and jurisdiction” in nearly all of the SCS. For example, the most extreme scenario would be if the ADIZ encompassed the entirety of Beijing’s “dashed-line” claim encircling the island waters of the SCS, an area equal to about 22 percent of China’s existing land territory and the vast majority of airspace in the SCS. Beijing may feel compelled to align the ADIZ with the dashed-line map in order to preserve, or at least not undermine, its claim. Note that the breadth and logic of this potential action would extend beyond past Chinese attempts to invoke security rights in the airspace above the EEZ in the SCS (e.g., the EP-3 incident of April 1, 2001) or the establishment of an ADIZ above the East China Sea (where China at least mimicked identification and control rules associated with extraterritorial ADIZs). A state’s legal ability to administer and use force to secure its sovereign territory and accompanying airspace is much broader than the right to self-defense in international airspace or within an ADIZ (¶ 10-11). Premise 1-the earlier ADIZ was a comprehensive disaster.  It has been basically unenforceable and has led to a series of unpleasant public relations disasters for China.  Not the least of which is breathing new life into a U.S.-centric containment policy amongst many of China's neighbors.  
Premise 2 - China does not need to declare such a status, as they can instead act in practice like it exists anyway.  
Premise 3-Slow and steady build-up and pressure has been a good strategy for China, so why rush, especially given premise 2.   Now if I am wrong about any of these presumptions, I will likely miss on this one.  But what makes this question especially hard for me are the conditions around Premise 3.  Maybe China thinks it's time to put on the big-boy pants and formalize things, in order to be more assertive in its claims.  We know they are threatening, and the media seems to believe them.  And the U.S. has been pressuring them, so a counter-move would be reasonably plausible.  But does that mean they will really do it relatively soon?  I am inclined to say no, as I believe they will just ignore the court ruling and continue to solidify their hold of the area by doing things like militarizing their fishing fleet and beefing up their "coast guard." The unique part of this one is the unilateral nature of China establishing one really without talking to anybody and doing it overlapping Taiwan, Japan and South Korea's — significantly over Japan's established ADIZ. Despite China's 2013 decision to form an Air-Defense Identification Zone over the East China Sea, I see a very low probability of there being one formed above the South China Sea any time soon. Their previous decision seemed to have come in response to the AirSea Battle Doctrine (renamed the Joint Concept for Access and Maneuver in the Global Commons), where the Navy and the Air Force worked together on plans to enable the U.S. government to be able to defeat adversaries who had the capability of denying the U.S. access to a certain region of their territory. This is most certainly the case with China as the U.S. has put a lot of stock into enabling free travel within the waterways around China for sailors of all backgrounds, inherently allowing the U.S. a greater chance of navigating these regions in order to properly prepare for a conflict. However, China claims that this act was in order to create newfound sovereignty in the East China Sea, as they lacked any control over the Diaoyu Islands, a characteristic that is not shared with the South China Sea. However, they have no way that they can attribute this decision to sovereignty for the South China Sea as Beijing has nearly full control over all of the maritime enterprises in the South China Sea. In fact, instead of showing a desire for sovereignty, it would just weaken the great relations China has with the countries in Southeast Asia due to border conflicts regarding the edge of the ADIZ in relationship to the island provinces that China and its neighbors currently control. Because of how these islands lie within the South China Sea, making a fair border is quite the challenging task as many of the islands are within a very close vicinity of islands belonging to other countries. Lastly, most analysts within China agree that the formulation of an Air-Defense Identification Zone wouldn't do anything productive for China, and could just serve as a way to aggravate those countries around them. On the flip side, there is still very much so a chance of the initiation of an ADIZ over the South China Sea if China decides they still want to attempt to repel the United States who has been increasing naval presence in the South China Sea (http://nationalinterest.org/feature/chinas-east-china-sea-adiz-gamble-past-present-south-china-13150). As well, the People’s Liberation Army in China, controlled by the Communist Party, have full control over the decisions regarding the potential employment of an Air-Defense Identification Zone in the South China Sea. This is unfortunate for those who hope it isn't formed as the Communist Party has a much more aggressive stance on the issue (http://foreignpolicy.com/2015/06/04/should-beijing-establish-an-air-defense-identification-zone-over-the-south-china-sea/). Lastly, China seemed to have tried to test their power back in 2015 when they flew an armed fighter jet over a part of the South China Sea after a U.S. battleship, the USS Lassen, had traversed the South China Sea (http://nationalinterest.org/blog/the-buzz/china-strikes-back-the-south-china-sea-adiz-style-14234).

Repost of my Oct. 12 analysis: There appears to be a wide gulf between forecasters who see establishment of a South China Sea ADIZ as highly likely and those who see it as highly unlikely. In the hope of reducing this gulf, here are some facts about ADIZs. 1. There are no international agreements governing any aspect of an ADIZ. States are neither explicitly authorized to establish them nor are they explicitly prohibited from doing so. ADIZs usually extend into what is universally acknowledged to be international airspace, even by the countries that maintain them, and in no way confer any sovereign rights. https://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/east-asia/2013-12-09/whats-adiz 2. The central distinction between China’s ADIZ and that of other countries, like the United States, is that China requires all planes that enter the ADIZ to notify China in advance, even if they do not plan to land at a Chinese airport. The ADIZs of the United States, for example, only require advanced notification of those planes planning to land. http://thediplomat.com/2013/12/chinas-puzzling-adiz-decision-making/ 3. The proposed (by commentators, not China) South China Sea ADIZ would cover a region through which aircraft of many nations fly. 4. Official rules for U.S. and Canadian ADIZs. https://www.faasafety.gov/files/gslac/library/documents/2011/Jan/49877/ADIZ%20TFR%20Intercepts%20w%20answers.pdf 5. U.S. and Japanese military aircraft have routinely defied the South China Sea ADIZ. See several of my previous forecasts for links to news stories. 6. The three ways to enforce an ADIZ are diplomacy, harassment of intruding aircraft sufficiently well as to drive them back – requires that the defender has better fighters than the intruders – or, that failing, destruction of intruders. During the Cold War, these activities between the U.S. and U.S.S.R. are rumored to have caused classified fatalities and known to have cause unclassified fatalities. More recently, Turkey has been shooting down Syrian aircraft that have invaded its airspace. http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2015/10/turkey-syria-russia-airspace-violations-militants-infiltrate.html Next, comparison class. Repost of my Oct. 12 analysis: There appears to be a wide gulf between forecasters who see establishment of a South China Sea ADIZ as highly likely and those who see it as highly unlikely. In the hope of reducing this gulf, here are some facts about ADIZs. 1. There are no international agreements governing any aspect of an ADIZ. States are neither explicitly authorized to establish them nor are they explicitly prohibited from doing so. ADIZs usually extend into what is universally acknowledged to be international airspace, even by the countries that maintain them, and in no way confer any sovereign rights. https://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/east-asia/2013-12-09/whats-adiz 2. The central distinction between China’s ADIZ and that of other countries, like the United States, is that China requires all planes that enter the ADIZ to notify China in advance, even if they do not plan to land at a Chinese airport. The ADIZs of the United States, for example, only require advanced notification of those planes planning to land. http://thediplomat.com/2013/12/chinas-puzzling-adiz-decision-making/ 3. The proposed (by commentators, not China) South China Sea ADIZ would cover a region through which aircraft of many nations fly. 4. Official rules for U.S. and Canadian ADIZs. https://www.faasafety.gov/files/gslac/library/documents/2011/Jan/49877/ADIZ%20TFR%20Intercepts%20w%20answers.pdf 5. U.S. and Japanese military aircraft have routinely defied the South China Sea ADIZ. See several of my previous forecasts for links to news stories. 6. The three ways to enforce an ADIZ are diplomacy, harassment of intruding aircraft sufficiently well as to drive them back – requires that the defender has better fighters than the intruders – or, that failing, destruction of intruders. During the Cold War, these activities between the U.S. and U.S.S.R. are rumored to have caused classified fatalities and known to have cause unclassified fatalities. More recently, Turkey has been shooting down Syrian aircraft that have invaded its airspace. http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2015/10/turkey-syria-russia-airspace-violations-militants-infiltrate.html Next, comparison class. The best comparison class would be the East China Sea ADIZ. So, how has the East China Sea ADIZ played out? Smart move, or humiliating debacle? “Almost all analysts inside China, including many affiliated with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, opposed the East China Sea ADIZ” June 4, 2015, http://foreignpolicy.com/2015/06/04/should-beijing-establish-an-air-defense-identification-zone-over-the-south-china-sea/ “It is unrealistic to expect China to walk back its ADIZ unilaterally. Initial Thoughts (28/10/2015): This question requires two predictions: 1) Will China create a South China Sea ADIZ, and; 2) what shape would it take. Taking both these things into consideration (also in light of the USS Lassen's Passage near to Fiery Cross Reef's Chinese runway project), I suspect that China will not create a new ADIZ in the region without being dramatically provoked by other claimants, the probability of which I expect to also be low. Starting with the second part first, the shape could correspond closely to the Exclusive Economic Zone or it could extend to cover all or part of the 9-Dotted Line to encompass all or part of the Spratly Islands. A conservative ADIZ is unlikely because it would appear to be a smaller region than claimed as their rightful territory, thereby locking in a loss. A larger territory would therefore be the preferred option. However, the chances of a new Chinese ADIZ in this region are low due to the military postures of the rival countries in this area (Taiwan, Vietnam, Malaysia, Brunei, and The Philippines), compared to Taiwan, Japan and South Korea in the East China Sea disputes. The East China Sea disputes revolve around locations over which other countries actively exercise possession: the Senkaku Islands (Japan) and Socotra Rock (South Korea), requiring China to escalate matters in order to force a resolution in their favor. However, the situation in the Spratly's is somewhat reversed, with China directly and indirectly (via Taiwan) possessing key locations, which puts the onus on other actors to provoke them to force a change. The distance and widely scattered nature of the Spratly Islands also somewhat diffuses tensions. The US may appear to provoke the Chinese to influence the US election cycle, but the preferred result for both China and the current party of the US executive is a benign display of US power projection followed by a Chinese display of mild annoyance tempered with infinite patience.

There appears to be a wide gulf between forecasters who see establishment of a South China Sea ADIZ as highly likely and those who see it as highly unlikely. In the hope of reducing this gulf, here are some facts about ADIZs. 1. There are no international agreements governing any aspect of an ADIZ. States are neither explicitly authorized to establish them nor are they explicitly prohibited from doing so. ADIZs usually extend into what is universally acknowledged to be international airspace, even by the countries that maintain them, and in no way confer any sovereign rights. https://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/east-asia/2013-12-09/whats-adiz 2. The central distinction between China’s ADIZ and that of other countries, like the United States, is that China requires all planes that enter the ADIZ to notify China in advance, even if they do not plan to land at a Chinese airport. The ADIZs of the United States, for example, only require advanced notification of those planes planning to land. http://thediplomat.com/2013/12/chinas-puzzling-adiz-decision-making/ 3. The proposed (by commentators, not China) South China Sea ADIZ would cover a region through which aircraft of many nations fly. 4. Official rules for U.S. and Canadian ADIZs. https://www.faasafety.gov/files/gslac/library/documents/2011/Jan/49877/ADIZ%20TFR%20Intercepts%20w%20answers.pdf 5. U.S. and Japanese military aircraft have routinely defied the South China Sea ADIZ. See several of my previous forecasts for links to news stories. 6. The three ways to enforce an ADIZ are diplomacy, harassment of intruding aircraft sufficiently well as to drive them back – requires that the defender has better fighters than the intruders – or, that failing, destruction of intruders. During the Cold War, these activities between the U.S. and U.S.S.R. are rumored to have caused classified fatalities and known to have cause unclassified fatalities. More recently, Turkey has been shooting down Syrian aircraft that have invaded its airspace.  http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2015/10/turkey-syria-russia-airspace-violations-militants-infiltrate.html Next, comparison class. The main purpose of these zones is not air defense, but rather symbolic politics. These countries want to underscore their territorial claims to certain islands located within the ADIZ. But these claims cannot be justified under international law by simply declaring an ADIZ. These countries are rather sending the political signal: "We are entitled to these islands." This holds very true with regards the construction of the islands in the South China Sea. For example, the most extreme scenario would be if the ADIZ encompassed the entirety of Beijing’s “dashed-line” claim encircling the island waters of the SCS, an area equal to about 22 percent of China’s existing land territory and the vast majority of airspace in the SCS. As of now, the ROC-Taiwan province is not part of the East China ADIZ established in November, 2013 by the PRC. To extent the East China ADIZ south "to cover part of the South China Sea"  would mean including that region. This would be more than a bold move by the PRC in peace-time.  It would lead to direct and daily confrontation with the government in Taipei, and into confrontation directly with the US.  Extension south is not an alternative. A separate South China Sea ADIZ could be established which does not directly confront ROC-Taiwan or the US, but would  directly confront Philippines and  Vietnam, both who hold and occupy territory there.  The timing of this move would necessary be well before 1OCT2016.   In the late Spring  or early Summer of 2016, for example. While a later declaration in 2016 is possible one must take into account  the "wet" season(s) in parts of the South China Sea. While the EAM season begins in mid-May and is essentially over by November in the East China Sea leading to the long Winter dry season (thus the declaration of that ADIZ in November, 2013), this is not so in the islands of the South China Sea.  It can be varied and continue late into the year.  Remember the deadliest storm to strike the Philippines was Typhoon Yolanda in November 8, 2013.  ADIZs are not just "declared" like a parlor game.  They must be defended in the 21st Century. That China is building airbases on the rocks and coral reeves of the South China Sea ( threatening the Second Thomas Shoal, but focusing on the Spraetleys)  does give weight to the assessment that it will declare an ADIZ there.  That the PRC and Russia have just finished the largest naval exercise in history in the region (28AUG15) projects a strong edge in the Pacific. Yet following this unified show of naval forces, the PRC has not declared an South China Sea ADIZ.   The motivating reason for the East China ADIZ was the Hainan Island Incident in 2001. That was 12 years in the works. Neither the PRC nor the US wish to repeat anything similar at present. The question remains: Does the PRC need to declare a South China Sea ADIZ by mid-2016?  Does it gain anything by doing so?  For now this is my forecast...
